I'm not a doctor either, but I might be able to help. The emplate:Orthopedic examination has atella tap in the section linking to nee examination. The section of the article that Ozzie supplied links to atellar tap (note the difference) in the context of nee effusion - what we would call "water-on-the knee". This is unrelated to atellar reflex which is a neurological test, not an orthopedic one. The patella tap is quite well described in e.g. http://patient.info/doctor/knee-assessment: uote|extend the knee and empty the suprapatellar pouch by applying pressure from the palm of your hand above the knee. This will push fluid underneath the patella, lifting it. Maintain this pressure. Next, press down on the patella with the fingers of the other hand and the patella will be felt to move down and touch ('tap') the underlying bone if an effusion is present. So there should be no problem in writing at least a stub for atellar tap (which most Google hits seem to use). In the meantime, I'll change the link in nee examination #Palpation from ffusion to nee effusion as the former really isn't relevant; and I'll change the redlink in emplate:Orthopedic examination to Patellar with an 'r' to fit the sources I found.. --ser:RexxS|RexxS (ser talk:RexxS|talk) 14:26, 26 April 2016 (UTC)
